# How compression sportswear actually works

Compression sportswear is a modern miracle. It builds confidence, helps you
recover from injury and makes you work harder... and the advantages don’t end
with fitness, says GQ’s snugly fitted scribe

By Tony Parsons

3 August 2020

Ivan Ryabokon / Alamy Stock Vector

Compression sportswear is nipple-crunching, stomach-flattening, scrotum-
lifting, -buttock- clenching, spine-straightening tight. As tight as a full-
body condom. As tight as the Dark Knight’s underpants. Tighter than anything
you have ever worn in your life. Once only seen on elite -athletes,
compression sportswear is suddenly turning up everywhere.

The weekend runner in the park, the commuter cyclist hurtling through a red
light, the weekend footballer who would not dream of wearing a jockstrap under
his shorts – you see skintight compression sportswear -everywhere these days,
on ordinary gym rats as much as elite athletes. And whatever else it may do,
there’s no doubting that just putting on compression sportswear seriously
changes your mood. “There’s no room for punks in suits,”says Aaron Taylor-
Johnson in _Kick-Ass 2_. “Just real heroes. Who can really kick ass.”

Compression sportswear is empowering, enabling. You put it on and you
immediately banish your inner Clark Kent and embrace your secret Superman. You
can’t slob out on the sofa in compression sportswear. You peel it on – it can
take a while – and don’t feel like ordering a takeaway pizza and turning on
the football. Not in gear so tight that it literally changes your posture.

“Go harder, go longer, go again,” it says on the box my Skins compression kit
came in and you never doubt that you will. Donning compression sportswear will
not turn you into Usain Bolt. It will not mean you are never -physically
exhausted. But you will be energised, in both your body and mind. It makes you
feel better – about everything. Even if you are only going to the gym, you
will look at yourself in a full-length mirror and feel, quite frankly, like
fighting evil.

My knee went. That is how I came to compression sportswear. Desperate,
limping, frustrated that strained medial ligaments in my knee had sent my
usual training routine right out the window. And afraid that this is what my
future looked like.

So I tried compression gear. I looked like a Stan Lee character – but my knee
got better

You have to learn to listen to your body. That is the great secret to managing
the cruel passage of time. Listen to your body and it will tell you when it
needs rest, when it needs ice, when it needs to be stretched. Listen to your
body and you will live long and have a good-looking corpse. And my body told
me – you should start wearing that compression sportswear.

We already know that compression is crucial for any soft-tissue injuries.
There it stands in the acronym RICE – rest, ice, compression and elevation.
The compression kit that you can buy from specialists such as Skins, Under
Armour, 2XU, Zensah and Lurbel, or indeed Nike and Adidas, is not exactly the
same as the compressionwear doctors recommend after surgery because some of
that stuff is so tight that it requires a prescription. But the principle
remains exactly the same.

Pressure reduces inflammation, increases blood circulation, lessens lactic
acid and improves recovery rate. So I tried compression gear – socks at first,
then shorts, then a T-shirt, then a long-sleeve shirt and pants. I looked like
a Stan Lee character. But my knee got better.

Many are the fads and fashion of sportswear. Liverpool’s Robbie Fowler once
wore an anti-snoring nose plaster, all the better to open his nasal passages.
Arsenal’s Patrick Vieira once took to the pitch with a dollop of vapour rub
staining the front of his shirt to help those midfielder’s muscles get as much
oxygen as possible. But what footballer wears a nose plaster on his hooter
these days? And who sticks vapour rub on their shirt now? Until compression
came along, the most successful sportswear trend in recent years was Kinesio
tape – those strips of often brightly coloured tape that are meant to relieve
pain and ease muscles in movement. Invented by a Japanese doctor called Kenzo
Kase 30 years ago, it was enormously popular with footballers. Mario Balotelli
wore Kinesio tape on his back, David Beckham wore it on his ribs and Gareth
Bale wore it on his thighs when he was at Spurs. And at London 2012, it was
all over the aching limbs of the track and field athletes. Today’s hot
sportswear fad can quickly become yesterday’s lukewarm fashion accessory.
Fowler’s nose plaster and Vieira’s vapour rub now look as fanciful as Eric
Cantona wearing his shirt collar turned up or John Terry sporting his socks
above his knee, a moment in time as fleeting as footballers in Alice bands,
snoods and headbands.

Compression sportswear is a bit different because the science behind it has
been around for almost a century. And it was developed not to enable superstar
sportsmen. But to heal the sick.

From the middle of the 20th century, doctors and physicians used compression
garments to treat patients who were recovering from surgery, fractures, burns,
lymphedema, arthritis, varicose veins and deep vein thrombosis. For more than
60 years, the world has known the benefits of compression. And then somebody
smart asked - if it works for the infirm, then why wouldn’t it work for the
fit?

Compression sportswear really began life in 1987 when a study in the American
Journal Of Physical Medicine by two doctors called Michael J Berry and Robert
G McMurray revealed that athletes wearing -compression stockings recovered a
lot faster than -athletes not wearing compression stockings.

Today an Olympic athlete in his physical prime and the pensioner who just had
surgery on his varicose veins wear compression stockings for the same reason –
to get the blood pumping and to aid recovery. The athletes who demand the most
from their bodies became the poster boys and girls of compression sportswear –
long-distance runners, cyclists and triathletes. Especially triathletes.

Nowhere has compression sportswear made such an impact as among the elite
endurance athletes of the ironman triathlon, where they are so fit that a
2.4-mile swim, a 112-mile bike ride and a full marathon of 26.2 miles is their
idea of just one event. “Compression garments have infiltrated endurance
sports,” reported triathlete.com. “Triathletes of all levels are wearing the
skintight pants, socks, tops and sleeves.”

And does it really work? Nobody doubts that compression aids recovery, but
does it really improve -performance? “What makes it tough is it’s so
subjective,” says professional triathlete Andy Potts, who wears it both during
and after races.

“Personally, I notice a difference. I started wearing it in 2008 for recovery.
Putting the socks on after pushing so hard is part of the process, one of the
triggers to relax.”

When you see ironman competitors, the toughest and fittest athletes on the
planet, almost all of them squeezed into compression sportswear, it is
difficult to doubt the benefits. But beyond the triathlon community,- there
are plenty of top athletes who use it simply as an aid to recovery. Andrew
Osagie, London 2012 Olympic 800m finalist, wears calf-length compression socks
between races, not during them.

“When I’m competing, I wear them between rounds but otherwise it’s usually
only after intense training -sessions,” says Osagie. “I will put them on as
soon as possible after competing or training and will keep them on for as long
as possible, taking them off before I go to bed. The main benefit I feel is
that my legs don’t feel as heavy. I never wear them during training. When I
did use them I seemed to get more tired towards the end of my sessions. That
said, I think they are great for recovery.”

At London 2012, the Australian equestrian team put their horses in brightly
coloured compression wear when they were back at the stables. Olympic gold
medallist Stuart Tinney said, “I am confident it helps the horses’ muscles
relax and recover after exercise.”

It works best if you believe it works. And believing is the most powerful
thing in the world

Australians love compression – Skins and 2XU are both Australian companies –
but one Aussie study said, “While the theoretical effects [of compression
sportswear] have been shown in trials, this doesn’t -necessarily translate
into better performance. However, many people love the feel of them – the feel
of the material- and the pressure on the skin, as well as the feeling of
support and reduced ‘wobble’. Anecdotally, many people who try them find they
provide a performance boost and they feel better afterwards.”

This kit works best if you believe it works. And -believing is the most
powerful thing in the world.

Every vision of tomorrow’s world over the last century has imagined future
woman dressing like Lieutenant Uhura, and future man looking like a superhero.
When it comes to retro--futurism, nipple-crushing clothes are more of a cliché
than flying cars. And as compression sportswear enters the mainstream, it
suddenly feels like the future is here. Shaun Ryder and the Happy Mondays got
it wrong. Don’t need no baggies in my wardrobe today. It’s got to be a tight
fit.

But a perfect fit is crucial. The manufacturer Skins is meticulous about
making sure you have the correct degree of pressure, and one blogger warned,
“A compression garment that exerts too much pressure may constrict blood flow
so you must make sure that you are wearing a garment that is the right size
for you and that has the technology necessary to apply a gradient and
controlled level of compression. If you are wearing a compression garment and
the area under the garment feels numb, starts turning cold or turns blue,
-discontinue use immediately.”

Compression sportswear is a bit like drugs. If you find yourself or a
companion turning blue, then something bad is happening. You have to get over
your shyness to wear this stuff. There’s definitely a blush barrier to break
through. Even after carefully calibrating the correct size, it still looks
impossibly, ridiculously- small when you first take it out of the box.
Suddenly dressing like a superhero is not something any man can do lightly.
You have to peel it on, like putting on a pair of tights. This is not
something that comes -naturally to most men.

And compression sportswear is not exactly comfortable. But it is enormously
flattering. Rather than -emphasising your little physical defects, it smooths
them down, lifts them up and packs them in. The first time you see yourself in
full-body compression gear will not be a disappointing moment. I now wear it
when working, finding that it sharpens my mind, keeps me focused and more
immersed in the moment. And oh yes – it does give you enormous erections.

Forget Viagra and Cialis. If you want erections that you can hang your hat on,
the kind of unbidden boner you got around the time of your GCSEs, then nothing
beats compression sportswear and the absurdly -invigorating effect it has on
your blood circulation.

The improved blood circulation you get with -compression sportswear means
better brain function, enhanced cell growth and upgraded organ function –
including the most vital organ of all. Now every man can be a superhero. But
is that a batphone in your pocket or are you just pleased to see me?
